# Commutative Algebra

# Algebras

# Graded AAA-algebra

Let AAA be a ring. A graded AAA-algebra is an AAA-algebra RRR which is also a graded ring, i.e. if r∈Rdr \in R_{d}r∈Rd​ then ar∈Rdar \in R_{d}ar∈Rd​ for all a∈Aa \in Aa∈A. That is to say that RdR_{d}Rd​ is an AAA-submodule of RRR for each d≥0d \geq 0d≥0.

# Cartesian Product

Let AAA be a fixed ring, and let R,SR, SR,S be graded AAA-algebras. Their cartesian product R×ASR \times_{A} SR×A​S is the graded AAA-module defined to the sum of the images of the AAA-module morphism

Rd⊗ASd⟶R⊗AS,for all d≥0. R_{d} \otimes_{A} S_{d} \longrightarrow R \otimes_{A} S,\qquad \text{for all } d \geq 0. Rd​⊗A​Sd​⟶R⊗A​S,for all d≥0.

This is a graded AAA-subalgebra of R⊗ASR\otimes_{A}SR⊗A​S, with the inherited grading

(R×AS)d≅Rd⊗ASd (R\times_{A}S)_{d} \cong R_{d} \otimes_{A} S_{d} (R×A​S)d​≅Rd​⊗A​Sd​

for each d≥0d \geq 0d≥0.

::: Lemma Let R,SR, SR,S be graded AAA-algebras. If RRR is generated by elements {ri}⊆R1\{r_{i}\}\subseteq R_{1}{ri​}⊆R1​ as an R0R_{0}R0​-algebra, and SSS is generated by elements {sj}⊆S1\{s_{j}\}\subseteq S_{1}{sj​}⊆S1​ as an S0S_{0}S0​-algebra, then R×ASR \times_{A} SR×A​S is generated by {ri⊗sj}⊆(R×AS)1\{ r_{i} \otimes s_{j} \} \subseteq (R \times_{A} S)_{1}{ri​⊗sj​}⊆(R×A​S)1​ as an (R×AS)0(R \times_{A} S)_{0}(R×A​S)0​-algebra. :::

# Rees Algebra

For an ideal III in a commutative ring TTT, the Rees algebra R[It]R[It]R[It] is defined to be

R[It]=⨁n=0∞Intn⊆R[t] R[It] = \bigoplus_{n=0}^{\infty}I^{n}t^{n} \subseteq R[t] R[It]=n=0⨁∞​Intn⊆R[t]
